Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Reconfigurable Traveling Wave Silicon Integrated Circuits for Millimeter-Wave Testing

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to demonstrate a millimeter-wave network analysis system that operates at frequencies between 100 and 300 GHz where existing test and measurement solutions are difficult and costly. The approach is to develop wideband, reconfigurable high-frequency circuits that employ a recently discovered traveling wave circuit technique called constructive wave amplification. By introducing localized shunt feedback networks along a single transmission line, traveling wave propagation may be altered through changes to the shunt feedback network. Waves traveling in either direction may be amplified over a wide range of frequencies.

The intellectual merit of this project includes the invention of reconfigurable, millimeter-wave circuits that advance both the state-of-the-art for millimeter-wave circuit design as well as test capabilities. Constructive wave amplification is a transformative aspect to this research because it relaxes known high-frequency transistor limitations. The research effort includes the theoretical analysis of the proposed approaches as well as experimental verification using silicon integrated circuit processes.

The broader impacts of this project include the development of enabling technologies for new scientific, medical, and industrial applications at millimeter-wave frequencies. The proposed monolithic integration of high-frequency circuitry could lead to substantially reduced cost of network analysis. The integrated educational plan includes incorporation of principles of millimeter-wave circuit design and measurement into undergraduate and graduate level courses. To bring the research outcomes to a broader audience, the principal investigator will create a series of instructional videos available online that introduce students at the high-school, undergraduate, and graduate levels to radio frequency circuit design, test, and measurement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this project have impacted the development of future wireless communication and sensing systems that will be needed to keep pace with growth of mobile software and virtualization applications running on cloud networks. While the current RF spectrum used for WiFi and cellular communication has become congested and data rates in these frequency bands are running into technical limitations, higher frequency spectrum in the millimeter-wave regime (above 30 GHz) poses an excellent opportunity for expanding wireless service capabilities both through backhaul infrastructure and access networks with greater available bandwidth and spatial directivity. Two problems have confronted the commercial development of millimeter-wave systems: 1) the underlying fundamental higher power consumption of the circuits integrated in semiconductor chips that are fast enough to operate at these frequencies and 2) the high cost to manufacture and test circuits at these frequency bands. This project investigated the fundamental limits of millimeter-wave circuits and systems based on CMOS and SiGe BiCMOS devices to answer each of these questions. While the focus of this project is on reducing the cost to test semiconductor chips that might operate in millimeter-wave bands, the broader outcomes include considering how communication circuits might be designed to increase system functionality in millimeter-wave phased arrays to form beams including (simultaneous) operation in both transmit and receive modes while sharing a common antenna array. We investigated traveling wave circuit implementations for high-frequency amplifiers and oscillators. Additionally, we investigated frequency conversion architectures for low-power phased array systems that could operate in transmit or receive modes. The educational outcomes have included the training of more than six Ph.D. graduate students who are now working in industry to advance the commercialization of millimeter-wave spectrum through the development of CMOS-based systems. During the duration of the program, undergraduate and M.S. students have been incorporated into the research activities. Finally, the PI has oriented undergraduate and graduate level teaching towards the challenges confronting future wireless communication circuit design including teaching high-frequency integrated circuit design in CMOS, the design of passive electromagnetic structures and CAD techniques that are compatible with planer semiconductor processes, and system-level simulation for millimeter-wave systems.  The outcomes of this research activity have been disseminated in more than 10 referred journal and conference papers that report the research contributions of graduate research assistants engaged in this project and acknowledge the contributions of federal funding. Additionally, the PI has voluntarily contributed to several conference workshops and technical journals to support the outcomes of this research activity.
